Award.AwardTitle: Extensions of Heegaard Floer Homology and Applications to Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Low-dimensional topology studies the shapes of spaces in dimensions one through four, and has applications ranging from physics and cosmology (the shape of the universe) to biochemistry (understanding the behavior of knotted DNA). Closely related to the study of 3- and 4-dimensional spaces is the study of knots (loops tied in space). In the early 2000s, Ozsvath and Szabo developed a package of powerful invariants for knots and 3- and 4-dimensional spaces, generally known as Heegaard-Floer homology. Heegaard-Floer homology has since taken a major place in low-dimensional topology, and has helped obtain a lot of new results and settle numerous old conjectures. The PI and her collaborator have developed a new algebraic technique for studying the variant for knots (knot Floer homology), by cutting a knot into pieces called tangles, and studying the individual pieces and their gluing. This NSF funded project seeks to develop further this new tool called tangle Floer homology, and use it to study knot theory problems and to better understand the relation between various knot invariants. The PI will aim to involve undergraduate and graduate students in aspects of the project that have combinatorial and computational nature, and will continue to promote mathematics to a broader audience.

Specific components of the project are to: 1) fully develop the ''minus" version of tangle Floer homology and introduce new concordance invariants, as well as extend tangle Floer homology to integer coefficients; 2) understand and develop the connections between knot Floer homology and quantum algebra, in order to relate existing knot invariants as well as obtain new ones; 3) use tangle Floer homology to carry out computations in knot Floer homology and to study problems on knot and link concordance, mutation, string links, and periodic knots.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aimed to study problems in low-dimensional topology using Heegaard Floer homology, a package of invariants of knots, links, 3- and 4-dimensional spaces, developed by Ozsvath and Sazbo. Most of the research funded by this grant focused on cut-and-paste methods in Heegaard Floer homology. These methods use algebraic invariants for 3-manifolds with boundary (called “bordered Floer homology”, developed by Lipshitz, Ozsvath, and Thurston, and generalized by Zarev) and for tangles (called “tangle Floer homology”, developed by the PI and Vera Vertesi). 

Over the course of this grant, the PI published three papers, produced a preprint that is under review for publication, and has been working on several more papers that are in preparation. These products branch out in different directions, and I briefly summarize them below. 

With Alexander Ellis and Vera Vertesi, We fit knot Floer homology in the Reshetikhin–Turaev framework of defining knot invariants from quantum algebra, showing that tangle Floer homology is a “weak” categorification of the quantum algebra for gl(1|1). With Mike Wong, we proved combinatorially that tangle Floer homology satisfies unoriented and oriented skein relations (relations among the invariants for a triple of links that only differ from one another in a small region), which are analogues of the skein exact triangles for knot Floer homology; the oriented skein relation can be seen as another step towards the development of knot Floer homology in the framework of categorification. With Biji Wong, we used bordered Floer homology to show that certain knot satellites are not Floer homologically “thin” (i.e. their knot Floer homology does not look like that of alternating knots) and studied various topological properties of these satellites. With Vladimir Chernov and Gage Martin, we showed that Khovanov homology, another invariant of knots and links, detects causality in certain (2+1)-dimensional spacetimes. The two main collaborations in progress which started while the PI was supported by this grant concern extending bordered Floer homology to a theory with integer coefficients (currently only defined over the field of characteristic two), and defining an invariant in bordered Floer homology for contact 3-manifolds with boundary. 

During the grant period, the PI traveled domestically and internationally to deliver lectures on her work and meet with collaborators. She has given outreach talks to high school students and to college undergraduates. She has advised 3 graduate students and mentored 2 postdocs, as well as delivered multiple topics courses and reading courses on her research.

 


Last Modified: 11/23/2020
Modified by: Ina Petkova
